info.name: Control Source
info.description: External cybernetic systems providing regulatory signals and coordination information to maintain system performance and environmental coupling, representing the fundamental principle that no system operates in isolation from control mechanisms

info.name: Environment Source
info.description: External entities supplying essential resources the system requires for operation, demonstrating how systems exist within resource networks and environmental dependencies, embodying the open system principle

info.name: Environment Waste Sink
info.description: Environmental systems that absorb, process, or neutralize waste outputs, critical for system sustainability and environmental health, representing the circular nature of matter and energy flows in system networks

info.name: Environment Sink
info.description: External entities receiving and utilizing the system's products, representing the 'customers' or beneficiaries demonstrating how systems exist within larger networks of interdependence and value creation

info.name: Input Processor
info.description: Subsystem demonstrating hierarchical organization and recursive system definition. Following Mobus: 'The procedure is one of deep analysis meaning that it guides a recursive process exposing increasingly deep details of subsystems and components.' This processor transforms incoming resources and prepares them for internal system transformation, embodying the principle of atomic processes at the decomposition leaf nodes.

info.name: Processing Boundary
info.description: Internal boundary separating input processing from core transformation activities, implementing the principle that boundaries regulate interactions between system levels

info.name: Resource Transfer Interface
info.description: Boundary mechanism enabling controlled flow of processed resources to central coordination

interfaces.protocol: 1. Input received and validated → 2. Processing parameters established → 3. Transformation algorithms executed → 4. Quality control verification → 5. Transfer to core system initiated

info.name: System
info.description: Generic system demonstrating the fundamental 7-tuple structure underlying all systems. As Mobus defines: 'a system S is a 7-tuple: S(i,l) = <C, N, G, B, T, H, Δt>(i,l)' where C=components, N=network relations, G=governance, B=boundary, T=transformation functions, H=history, Δt=time constants. This template embodies the universal systemness that exists in all domains - biological, social, technical, and abstract. Following the principle of recursive system definition, this demonstrates how 'all systems can be understood in the same framework of systemness' providing both scientific understanding and design foundation. The system language (SL) represents these elements through 'generic terms to represent various elements of systemness' that can be translated into domain-specific implementations while preserving fundamental system principles.

info.name: System Boundary
info.description: The conceptual or physical barrier separating the system from its environment. As Mobus explains: 'boundaries are kept intact by virtue of internal binding that produces an effective boundary. The distinction between what is inside versus outside depends on this effective boundary.' Boundaries can be fuzzy and porous while remaining functionally significant for system integrity and identity preservation.

info.name: Waste Export Interface
info.description: Specialized boundary mechanisms for expelling waste products, designed for safe and efficient waste removal rather than controlled product delivery, maintaining system cleanliness and environmental responsibility

interfaces.protocol: 1. Waste products identified and categorized → 2. Disposal pathway selected → 3. Safety protocols activated → 4. Environmental transfer executed → 5. System cleanliness restored

info.name: Product Output Interface
info.description: Specialized mechanism for delivering system products to environment. As Mobus defines: 'Interfaces are associated with the boundary of a system... they act as pass-ways for inputs and outputs.' These manage controlled delivery of system value to external beneficiaries.

interfaces.protocol: 1. Product quality verified → 2. Output specifications confirmed → 3. Delivery mechanisms activated → 4. Transfer to environment executed → 5. Feedback loop completed

info.name: Control Signal Interface
info.description: Specialized interfaces for receiving and processing control information enabling system responsiveness and adaptation through regulated information exchange. Every interface includes protocol objects for systematic interaction.

interfaces.protocol: 1. Control signals received and decoded → 2. System parameters adjusted → 3. Coordination mechanisms activated → 4. Response patterns implemented → 5. Feedback confirmation transmitted

info.name: Resource Input Interface
info.description: Boundary mechanisms that selectively allow needed resources to enter the system. Input interfaces include filtering and selection capabilities ensuring only appropriate resources access internal processes

interfaces.protocol: 1. Resource availability detected → 2. Selection criteria applied → 3. Quality verification performed → 4. Internal transport initiated → 5. Resource integration completed

info.name: Output Generator
info.description: Subsystem generating and packaging the system's primary products for environmental delivery. Following the principle that 'structure and function may be the very same thing: structures are the expression of a flow of processes.' This demonstrates how transformation processes are distributed across subsystem networks rather than occurring at single points.

info.name: Production Boundary
info.description: Boundary separating final product generation from core processing activities, embodying the concept of 'internal binding' that maintains subsystem integrity while enabling system-wide coordination

info.name: Control Processor
info.description: Subsystem processing control signals and regulatory information from the environment. Systems display 'automatic-rhythmic activities' and regulation processes. This subsystem embodies regulatory function at the subsystem level, demonstrating recursive control principles throughout the hierarchy of organization.

info.name: Control Boundary
info.description: Specialized boundary for information processing and signal interpretation, implementing the principle that 'boundary elements provide interfaces' for environmental coordination and system adaptation

info.name: Coordination Signal Interface
info.description: Interface for transmitting processed control information to central system coordination

interfaces.protocol: 1. Control data analyzed and interpreted → 2. System coordination requirements determined → 3. Regulatory parameters calculated → 4. Coordination signals generated → 5. Central system notification completed

info.name: Waste Manager
info.description: Subsystem handling waste processing and disposal, ensuring system sustainability. Systems require 'homeostasis' - processes that maintain system integrity, including waste management. This demonstrates how waste management requires systematic organization and specialized subsystem capabilities for system health.

info.name: Waste Management Boundary
info.description: Boundary containing waste processing activities and preventing contamination of core system processes, implementing the principle of 'effective boundary' control at the subsystem level

info.name: Central Coordinator
info.description: Core coordination subsystem integrating inputs from boundary subsystems and orchestrating overall system transformation. Embodies the principle that 'structure and function may be the very same thing: structures are the expression of a flow of processes.' This subsystem contains the primary transformation function defining system purpose and coordinates the hierarchical network according to the recursive system definition.

info.name: Core Processing Boundary
info.description: Central boundary containing primary transformation processes and coordination mechanisms that define system identity and function, implementing both homeostatic regulation and internal binding principles

info.name: Product Coordination Interface
info.description: Interface managing the flow of processed materials to output generation subsystem

interfaces.protocol: 1. Processing completion verified → 2. Product specifications confirmed → 3. Output coordination initiated → 4. Quality parameters transmitted → 5. Production scheduling completed

info.name: Waste Coordination Interface
info.description: Interface managing waste product allocation and disposal scheduling for system cleanliness

interfaces.protocol: 1. Waste streams identified and categorized → 2. Disposal capacity assessed → 3. Processing schedules coordinated → 4. Waste transfer initiated → 5. System cleanliness maintained

info.name: Control Integration Interface
info.description: Interface receiving and integrating control information from regulatory subsystem

interfaces.protocol: 1. Control signals received and validated → 2. System state parameters updated → 3. Coordination adjustments calculated → 4. Integration protocols executed → 5. System optimization achieved

info.name: Resource Integration Interface
info.description: Interface receiving and coordinating processed resources from input subsystem

interfaces.protocol: 1. Processed resources received and verified → 2. Integration parameters established → 3. Resource allocation algorithms executed → 4. Processing coordination initiated → 5. System synchronization achieved

info.name: Waste Flow
info.description: Byproducts and waste materials generated during system operation. As Mobus notes: 'systems interface with entities in the environment that act as sinks for the wastes produced by the system.' All real systems produce waste through energy dissipation, unused materials, or degraded outputs requiring systematic disposal.

info.name: Product Flow
info.description: Primary output generated through system transformation processes. Following Mobus: 'Every system performs a work transformation on its inputs to produce its outputs.' This represents the system's main purpose - what it transforms inputs into for environmental benefit and system justification.

info.name: Control Flow
info.description: Information and signals regulating and coordinating system behavior. Following the network concept: 'flows of messages that link the components.' Control flows enable system adaptation and optimal operation maintenance in response to changing environmental conditions.

info.name: Resource Flow
info.description: Primary inputs and raw materials required for system function. As defined in system networks: 'flows of matter, energy, and messages that link the components.' Resources are transformed by the system into products through internal processes following transformation functions.

info.name: Processed Resource Flow
info.description: Resources processed by input subsystem and prepared for central coordination, demonstrating the flow of system transformation through hierarchical decomposition

info.name: Control Integration Flow
info.description: Processed control information flowing from regulatory subsystem to central coordination, enabling system adaptation and environmental responsiveness

info.name: Core Products
info.description: Primary products generated by core transformation processes, ready for final packaging and delivery, demonstrating the directional flow pattern from processing to production embodying transformation function concepts

info.name: Process Waste
info.description: Waste materials generated by core transformation processes requiring specialized handling and disposal, demonstrating that even waste flows follow systematic patterns in well-organized systems
